repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR is introducing pure python mode in language basics documentation. It is partial fix of https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187

comment_data.body:
I think we can avoid cluttering the example with type declarations when the type is "obviously" safe to infer.
```suggestion
    # Note that the variables below are automatically inferred
    # as the correct pointer type that is assigned to them.
    # They do not need to be typed explicitly.
    
    ptr = cython.cast(cython.p_void, python_string)
    adress_in_c = cython.cast(Py_intptr_t, ptr)
    address_from_void = adress_in_c        # address_from_void is a python int

    ptr2 = cython.cast(cython.pointer(PyObject), python_string)
    address_in_c2 = cython.cast(Py_intptr_t, ptr2)
    address_from_PyObject = address_in_c2  # address_from_PyObject is a python int
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+from cython.cimports.cpython.ref import PyObject
+
+def main():
+
+    python_string = "foo"
+
+    ptr: p_void = cython.cast(cython.p_void, python_string)
+    adress_in_c: Py_intptr_t= cython.cast(Py_intptr_t, ptr)
+    address_from_void = adress_in_c        # address_from_void is a python int
+
+    ptr2: cython.pointer(PyObject) = cython.cast(cython.pointer(PyObject), python_string)
+    address_in_c2: Py_intptr_t= cython.cast(Py_intptr_t, ptr2)
+    address_from_PyObject = address_in_c2  # address_from_PyObject is a python int

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    p = fopen("spam.txt", "r")   # The type of "p" is "FILE*", as returned by fopen().
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdio import FILE, fopen
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdlib import malloc, free
+from cython.cimports.cpython.exc import PyErr_SetFromErrnoWithFilenameObject
+
+def open_file():
+    p: cython.pointer(FILE) = fopen("spam.txt", "r")

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    # Note that the type of the variable "my_array" is automatically inferred from the assignment.
    my_array = cython.cast(p_double, malloc(number * cython.sizeof(double)))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdio import FILE, fopen
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdlib import malloc, free
+from cython.cimports.cpython.exc import PyErr_SetFromErrnoWithFilenameObject
+
+def open_file():
+    p: cython.pointer(FILE) = fopen("spam.txt", "r")
+
+    if p is cython.NULL:
+        PyErr_SetFromErrnoWithFilenameObject(OSError, "spam.txt")
+    ...
+
+
+def allocating_memory(number=10):
+    my_array: cython.p_double = cython.cast(p_double, malloc(number * cython.sizeof(double)))

comment_data.body: This statement is incorrect for the Python version. Also, since type hints are ignored for global variables, this needs to use the explicit `cython.declare()` command.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,61 +48,104 @@ C variable and type definitions
 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level

comment_data.body: Interesting. I wasn't even aware of that. I created https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4252 to track it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,61 +48,104 @@ C variable and type definitions
 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            import cython
+
+            i: cython.int
+            j: cython.int
+            k: cython.int
+            f: cython.float
+            g: cython.int[42]
+            h: cython.p_float
+
+
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
 
-    cdef int i, j, k
-    cdef float f, g[42], *h
+            cdef int i, j, k
+            cdef float f, g[42], *h
 
 and C :keyword:`struct`, :keyword:`union` or :keyword:`enum` types:
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
+.. tabs::
 
-See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-.. note::
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.py
 
-    Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
-    the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+        .. NOTE:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums.

comment_data.body:
I don't think we need that much space here.
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,61 +48,104 @@ C variable and type definitions
 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            import cython
+
+            i: cython.int
+            j: cython.int
+            k: cython.int
+            f: cython.float
+            g: cython.int[42]
+            h: cython.p_float
+
+
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
 
-    cdef int i, j, k
-    cdef float f, g[42], *h
+            cdef int i, j, k
+            cdef float f, g[42], *h
 
 and C :keyword:`struct`, :keyword:`union` or :keyword:`enum` types:
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
+.. tabs::
 
-See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-.. note::
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.py
 
-    Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
-    the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+        .. NOTE:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums.
 
-Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-    cpdef enum CheeseState:
-        hard = 1
-        soft = 2
-        runny = 3
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
 
+        See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
 
+        .. note::
 
-There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
-an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
+            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
 
-    cdef enum:
-        tons_of_spam = 3
+        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
 
-.. note::
-    the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-    pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
+            cpdef enum CheeseState:
+                hard = 1
+                soft = 2
+                runny = 3
+
+
+

comment_data.body: This seems missing from the Python version, although it is supported.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,61 +48,104 @@ C variable and type definitions
 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            import cython
+
+            i: cython.int
+            j: cython.int
+            k: cython.int
+            f: cython.float
+            g: cython.int[42]
+            h: cython.p_float
+
+
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
 
-    cdef int i, j, k
-    cdef float f, g[42], *h
+            cdef int i, j, k
+            cdef float f, g[42], *h
 
 and C :keyword:`struct`, :keyword:`union` or :keyword:`enum` types:
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
+.. tabs::
 
-See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-.. note::
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.py
 
-    Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
-    the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+        .. NOTE:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums.
 
-Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-    cpdef enum CheeseState:
-        hard = 1
-        soft = 2
-        runny = 3
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
 
+        See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
 
+        .. note::
 
-There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
-an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
+            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
 
-    cdef enum:
-        tons_of_spam = 3
+        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
 
-.. note::
-    the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-    pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
+            cpdef enum CheeseState:
+                hard = 1
+                soft = 2
+                runny = 3
+
+
+
+        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
+        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
 
-        cdef Grail *gp
+            cdef enum:
+                tons_of_spam = 3
 
-    and not::
+        .. note::
+            the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
+            defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
+            pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
 
-        cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
+                cdef Grail *gp
 
-    There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::
+            and not::
 
-        ctypedef unsigned long ULong
+                cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
 
-        ctypedef int* IntPtr
+            There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::

comment_data.body: Looks like there's no way to do this in Python syntax. I created #4253 to track it.

-Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::

-        hard = 1

-an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
+            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
 
-    cdef enum:
-        tons_of_spam = 3
+        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
 
-.. note::
-    the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-    pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
+            cpdef enum CheeseState:
+                hard = 1
+                soft = 2
+                runny = 3
+
+
+
+        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
+        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
 
-        cdef Grail *gp
+            cdef enum:
+                tons_of_spam = 3
 
-    and not::
+        .. note::
+            the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
+            defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
+            pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
 
-        cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
+                cdef Grail *gp
 
-    There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::
+            and not::
 
-        ctypedef unsigned long ULong
+                cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
 
-        ctypedef int* IntPtr
+            There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::
+
+                ctypedef unsigned long ULong
+
+                ctypedef int* IntPtr
 
 
 It is also possible to declare functions with :keyword:`cdef`, making them c functions.

comment_data.body: This should better be wrapped in a function to make it actually do something. (Same below.)

 compile it.

-variable, and then obtain the ``char*`` from that, i.e.::
+variable, and then obtain the ``char*`` from that, i.e.
+

+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            s: cython.p_char
+            p = pystring1 + pystring2

comment_data.body:
> this needs to use the explicit `cython.declare()` command.

It would be very good to indicate this, for example in a comment or explanation, since this behavior has not yet been documented, although in a good way it belongs [here](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html).

It was worth trying to write enum, and what if it's .. `cython.enum` .., but by chance it's just not documented, lol

comment_data.body:
In addition, you can make the pure python version match the version with `cdef` just with `cython.declare()`.
i.e. `cython.declare(i=cython.int, j=cython.int, k=cython.int)`

and for alignment reasons, `import cython` is not needed here, especially since it has already been written about in `two-syntax-variants-used`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,61 +48,104 @@ C variable and type definitions
 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level

comment_data.body: The versions will not align here, it is easier to achieve by moving the code out to the file and adding a space to the line before the `cdef` line.

 ===============================
 
 The :keyword:`cdef` statement is used to declare C variables, either local or
-module-level::
+module-level

+        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
 
-.. note::
-    the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-    pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
+            cpdef enum CheeseState:
+                hard = 1
+                soft = 2
+                runny = 3
+
+        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
+        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+
+            cdef enum:

+
+        .. note::
+            the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
+            defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable

 When in a ``.pxd`` file, the signature is different like this example: ``cdef foo(x=*)``.

@@ -404,20 +581,48 @@ returns small results.
 
 If all possible return values are legal and you
 can't reserve one entirely for signalling errors, you can use an alternative
-form of exception value declaration::
+form of exception value declaration
 
-    cdef int spam() except? -1:
-        ...
+.. tabs::
+

 The "?" indicates that the value ``-1`` only signals a possible error. In this
 case, Cython generates a call to :c:func:`PyErr_Occurred` if the exception value
 is returned, to make sure it really received an exception and not just a normal
 result.
 
-There is also a third form of exception value declaration::
+There is also a third form of exception value declaration
 
-    cdef int spam() except *:
-        ...
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            @cython.exceptval(check=True)
+            def spam() -> cython.int:
+                ...
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            cdef int spam() except *:
+                ...

comment_data.body:
The ugly way to make this work in pure python is to use [numpy initialization](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/efdf996dced075682d86b7e53a12b56b5ebfea38/Cython/Includes/numpy/__init__.pxd#L28).
i.e. `from numpy cimport Py_intptr_t`

But, since this tutorial does not focus on the `extern` syntax, it is not clear what it is and how it works, so we can move this type definition somewhere in `Cython/Includes/cpython`

What do you think @scoder?

-    the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+        .. NOTE:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums.
 
-Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-    cpdef enum CheeseState:
-        hard = 1
-        soft = 2
-        runny = 3
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
 
+        See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
 
+        .. note::
 
-There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
-an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
+            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
 
-    cdef enum:
-        tons_of_spam = 3
+        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
 
-.. note::
-    the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-    pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
+            cpdef enum CheeseState:
+                hard = 1
+                soft = 2
+                runny = 3
+
+
+
+        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
+        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
 
-        cdef Grail *gp
+            cdef enum:
+                tons_of_spam = 3
 
-    and not::
+        .. note::
+            the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
+            defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
+            pointing to a ``Grail`` you would write::
 
-        cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
+                cdef Grail *gp
 
-    There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::
+            and not::
 
-        ctypedef unsigned long ULong
+                cdef struct Grail *gp # WRONG
 
-        ctypedef int* IntPtr
+            There is also a ``ctypedef`` statement for giving names to types, e.g.::

comment_data.body: done.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,28 +285,78 @@ there is a tiny overhead in calling a :keyword:`cpdef` method from Cython compar
 calling a :keyword:`cdef` method.
 
 Parameters of either type of function can be declared to have C data types,
-using normal C declaration syntax. For example,::
+using normal C declaration syntax. For example,
 
-    def spam(int i, char *s):
-        ...
+.. tabs::
 
-    cdef int eggs(unsigned long l, float f):
-        ...
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-``ctuples`` may also be used::
+        .. code-block:: python
 
-    cdef (int, float) chips((long, long, double) t):
-        ...
+            def spam(i: cython.int, s: cython.p_char):
+                ...
+
+            @cython.cfunc
+            def eggs(l: cython.ulong, f: cython.float) -> cython.int:
+                ...
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            def spam(int i, char *s):
+                ...
+
+
+            cdef int eggs(unsigned long l, float f):
+                ...
+
+
+
+``ctuples`` may also be used
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+         def chips(t: (cython.long, cython.long, cython.double)) -> (cython.int, cython.float)
+            ...
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            cdef (int, float) chips((long, long, double) t):
+                ...

comment_data.body:
> Why shouldn't annotations work here? They seem to explain the idea well.

I'm not talking about the idea, I said that in this case the annotations may not work as we want, and therefore I said to check if the cythonizaed versions correspond, if so, then there is nothing to worry about.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,28 +285,78 @@ there is a tiny overhead in calling a :keyword:`cpdef` method from Cython compar
 calling a :keyword:`cdef` method.
 
 Parameters of either type of function can be declared to have C data types,
-using normal C declaration syntax. For example,::
+using normal C declaration syntax. For example,
 
-    def spam(int i, char *s):
-        ...
+.. tabs::
 
-    cdef int eggs(unsigned long l, float f):
-        ...
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-``ctuples`` may also be used::
+        .. code-block:: python
 
-    cdef (int, float) chips((long, long, double) t):
-        ...
+            def spam(i: cython.int, s: cython.p_char):
+                ...
+
+            @cython.cfunc
+            def eggs(l: cython.ulong, f: cython.float) -> cython.int:
+                ...
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            def spam(int i, char *s):
+                ...
+
+
+            cdef int eggs(unsigned long l, float f):
+                ...
+
+
+
+``ctuples`` may also be used
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python

+         def chips(t: (cython.long, cython.long, cython.double)) -> (cython.int, cython.float)
+            ...

+    .. group-tab:: Cython

+            cdef (int, float) chips((long, long, double) t):
+                ...
 
 When a parameter of a Python function is declared to have a C data type, it is
 passed in as a Python object and automatically converted to a C value, if
 possible. In other words, the definition of ``spam`` above is equivalent to
-writing::
+writing
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            def spam(python_i, python_s):
+                i: cython.int = python_i
+                s: cython.p_char = python_s
+                ...
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            def spam(python_i, python_s):
+                cdef int i = python_i
+                cdef char* s = python_s
+                ...

comment_data.body: @scoder I would generally suggest covering C API path of `Python.h` with type declarations. Not necessarily in this PR, but it will be more pleasant if there are already `ctypedef `s for the cpython.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,2 @@
+cdef extern from *:
+    ctypedef Py_ssize_t Py_intptr_t

commit.message: Introduce pure python mode in language basics documentation
Move union documentation to cython tab
Note that DEF/IF/ELIF is not supported by pure python mode
Improve examples, added initial note about pure python

Remove redundant empty line

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

Don't specify type of variable when type can be automatically inferred.

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

Use automatic type inference in example

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

Use automatic type inference in example

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
Move ctypedef to pure python and minor fixes

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Introduce pure python mode in language basics documentation
